name: Solidarity HealthShare
statementOfFaith: Rooted in Sacred Scripture and Sacred Tradition of the Catholic Church. Members agree to live by biblical principles, practice solidarity, commit to the common good, and pursue a healthy lifestyle as the body is a 'temple of the Holy Spirit.'

preExisting.sharingLimits: Year 1: not shared. Year 2: up to $25,000. Year 3: additional $25,000. Year 4+: fully shareable.

bestFor: Catholic families seeking values-aligned ministry with strong mental health and maternity coverage
pros: First health sharing ministry to fully share mental health treatment (unlimited counseling, medication, hospitalization)
Comprehensive maternity coverage including hospitals, midwives, and home births
Alternative/integrative care covered (naturopathic, chiropractic, regenerative medicine)
Reference-based pricing saves 60-70% off billed charges
cons: Extremely slow claim processing — members report 6-24 months despite stated 90-120 day timeline
Very poor member satisfaction (1.4-1.6/5 across review sites)
No traditional provider network — reference-based pricing can cause balance billing disputes
Strict faith requirements including church attendance verification
aiSummary: Solidarity HealthShare is a Catholic-centered health sharing ministry founded in 2016 in Tempe, AZ with approximately 50,000 members. It offers three plans: Solidarity ONE (comprehensive, $149-$599/mo), SAVVY (young adults 18-29, starting at $85/mo), and SHIELD (catastrophic, starting at $67/mo). Uses reference-based pricing with no provider network. The ONE plan provides best-in-class mental health coverage (unlimited counseling, medication, hospitalization) and maternity including midwives and home births. Requires Catholic or Christian faith with church attendance. Major concerns include extremely slow claims processing (6-24 months reported) and poor member satisfaction ratings.
aiKeyFacts: Catholic faith requirement with church attendance
Best-in-class mental health coverage (unlimited on ONE plan)
Maternity includes hospitals, midwives, home births (ONE plan)
Severe claim processing delays reported (6-24 months)
